charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Charity organisations have typically struggled during the
pandemic in terms donations. A charity that is particularly close to home for me is Macmillan Cancer Support and I would like to do my bit to raise some money for a great cause. 

 As such, I will be running 100km during the month of February, starting on the 1st and finishing before 1st March, with Colm and Patrick Martin. We will be running 300KM in total and as such have set ourselves a target of raising £300.

We appreciate times are tough at the moment but would be extremely grateful for any donations you could spare to support their mission.

Every little bit will help me reach my goal. I've included
information about Macmillan Cancer Support below:

We’re here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as
they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever
cancer throws your way, we’re right there with you.

For information, support or just someone to talk to, send us a
private message, or call our Support Line free on 0808 808 00 00 (8am-8pm, 7
days a week). For other ways to contact us, please visit https://www.macmillan.org.uk/information-and-support.
If our lines are closed, The Samaritans are open 24/7 on 116 123. If you are
concerned about your health you must consult your doctor. To give, fundraise or
volunteer call our Supporter Care Hub on 0300 1000 200 or visit https://www.macmillan.org.uk/get-involved/all-ways-to-help.html To
allow us to focus our time on supporting those who need it most, we ask that
comments posted here be respectful, considerate and non-judgmental of other
users’ experiences. If you post comments that are abusive or offensive in
nature, or break Facebook’s own terms and conditions, we may need to hide your
comments or block you from our page. We kindly ask you to support us in
supporting others.

Although we make every effort to ensure accuracy, Macmillan

information such as other websites to which we link. Macmillan Cancer Support

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
The past 18 months have seen 3 family members affected by Cancer. Emma’s dad was diagnosed with bladder cancer after having no symptoms back in 2019. He underwent radiotherapy and spent the next 12 months recovering overcoming several complications along the way. Thankfully he is doing well and is having his regular checks. At the start of December my brother Graham began to pass blood in his urine. After a biopsy we were given the news just after Christmas that he has aggressive bladder cancer and would need surgery to fully remove his bladder changing his life forever. Around the same time Graham’s mother-in-law discovered a lump on her neck. Following a biopsy she has now been told she has thyroid cancer after battling the same disease 30 years ago. She will need to undergo surgery to have her thyroid removed and then there will be intensive treatment to follow.

So instead of wallowing and thinking life isn’t fair I have decided to embark on a 28 day challenge to not only push myself physically and mentally but also to hopefully raise money for MacMillan cancer whose tireless research and support work means that people are able to beat cancer.

I will be charting my progress on a daily basis  for you all to see and maybe have a giggle at.

Any donation that you can make no matter how big or small would be so appreciated and will help MacMillan continue with their outstanding work.

Thank you 

John

Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. story: While we're all still in lockdown and the days are cold and short, it's so important we're still getting out and exercising... not just for our hearts and physical health but for our mental wellbeing too! This Heart Month, our team are committing to walk/jog/run 100km (60 miles) and we'd love to get as many people across the community to join in on the challenge too. 100km might sound a lot, but over a month it works out at roughly 2 miles a day - that's roughly a 20min jog, or a 30 minute walk. We're asking everyone who takes part to set a target of £100 and help spread the word. If we get 60 people to join the team, then that's £6,000 raised for the BHF's 60th year to go towards life-saving research. If 2020 taught us anything, it's that research works! Some companies have decided to sponsor employees taking part £1/km up to £100 - an incredible initiative to encourage employees to stay active and take breaks away from their desks. Be creative, feel free to put your own spin on the challenge and have fun! *The page will be live until the end of March (and, depending on uptake, into April) so if you want to take part in the challenge once the weather warms up, that's totally fine too!

Most of you know about Jasper's condition and journey already, but for those of you that dont here is a brief summary.

Jasper was diagnosed with congenital heart defects at my 20 month scan. It was the most heartbreaking news I've ever had. I was given information leaflets provided by the British Heart Foundation which explained things and answered lots of questions. He had 3 open heart operations by the time he was 4 weeks old. He has had a long journey to recovery but he is doing well at the moment. He is now 6 months old and results of a recent ct scan have showed there is still a narrowing in the artery which leads to his lungs.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history, the NHS's budget is being stretched to the max due to coronavirus and it's led British Heart Foundation to make the devastating decision to cut their research budget in half. 

This a charity very close to my heart. I was diagnosed with a condition called superventricular tachychadia, (SVT) which is a heart condition affecting the electrical system of the heart predominantly in young, fit, healthy people. 

Currently the only cure for this condition is a type of heart surgery called an ablation, however, we are on the edge of ground-breaking research in the form of a nasal spray which can convert the heart back to it's normal pace and rhythm. More research has to be done but a development like this will make such a difference to so many people's lives. 

Luckily SVT when converted back in good time isn't life threatening, but other conditions such as heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers and we can't drop the ball now, research is the key to finding cures and improving the lives of so many people. 

I'd really appreciate if you could support this and give as little as you can to such an amazing cause.

story:
I was born with Spina Bifida - Lipomeningocele.  I had my first spinal surgery at 1 year of age preformed by Addenbrookes hospital in Cambridge.  My care was then transferred to Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH), where I was seen by my neurosurgeon Mr Dominic Thompson.  

Mr Dominic performed 2 pioneering surgeries on my spine at 10 and 12.  After my surgery at 12, I was in a wheelchair and was advised that it was highly unlikely that I would ever be able to walk more than 100 metres at a time. 

At the age of 14, I decided to push myself and attempt to walk as I couldn't stand feeling so depressed, weak and low in self-esteem.   To aid my recovery, I had to quit my pain killers and they dulled my mind and stop me from finding and using my drive.  It was painful and hard work but with the help of my family and physio team and Mr Dominic Thompson and GOSH I was able to walk fully about a year later.  

I have had ongoing issues my whole life and will soon have surgery to lengthen my left thigh to realign my hips and avoid further scoliosis.  Unfortunately, my surgery has been delayed due to COVID, so before my next op, I will be running/walking/crawling... the London Marathon 2021! 

Please help me raise money for GOSH so they can help more people live their lives to the fullest.

On 14th January 2021 our mum, Kath, sadly passed away at the great age of 91.

During the last couple of months of her life Marie Curie nurses came and looked after mum, their kindness, compassion and support not only towards her but to all of us was appreciated more than they will ever know and we will be eternally grateful.

It is our intention to run 91K and all proceeds will be given to Marie Curie so they can continue to give the support to another family in need.  There is a group of us all running and we would like to raise as much as we can, we know we are in difficult times but would appreciate any donations however small.  I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your support.  We are going to start on 17th March and completing the 91K by 30th April 2021.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The nearest Lifeboat Station to the Midlands might be over 100 miles away, but with 87% of residents of the Midlands visiting the coast each year, you don't have to live by the sea to support the RNLI.

The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown.

Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped.

Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.

The coasts of Wales and North West England are popular tourist destinations for millions of holidaymakers from the Midlands and we want to keep those coasts a safe place for everyone to visit.

The average lifeboat station in Wales, North West England and Isle of Man costs £159,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus.

We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

When you and your loved visit the coast, we will always be there to keep you safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on British coasts.

Please help us fulfil that mission by making a donation to our fundraising page, no matter how big or small.

Thank you.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
RNLI lifeboats in Scotland protect hundreds of communities with a 24-hour search and rescue service. Our volunteer crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. 
Scotlands unrivalled coasts and waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.
Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 46 of the lifeboat stations in Scotland is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. It costs an average of £155k to run a lifeboat station in Scotland but with the implications of Covid-19, we havent been able to fundraise as normal to help keep our lifeboats afloat. Can you help?

story:
Rentokil Initial has been supporting Malaria No More for over 10 years now, raising over £250,000 to date.

Every two minutes a child under 5 dies from malaria and yet, it is preventable and treatable. Since 2000 we’ve cut world malaria deaths by 60%, but that progress is in jeopardy and we need to step up efforts. By making a donation, you’ll be helping to protect children and their families from malaria, save lives and create a world where no child suffers needlessly. That means more kids in school, more people in work, less pressure on health services. A future with less poverty and more economic growth.

Rentokil Initial has 20 teams of 20 colleagues from across the world completing a challenge to Race to Kigali - boosting their activity over three months & fundraising along the virtual course. Kigali in Rwanda is c. 9000km from the RI Head office in the UK - it's where Malaria No More will be meeting the Commonwealth Heads of Government in 2021 to secure vital funds and focus on saving lives from malaria.

charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

story: Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities. I spent 7 months in Madagascar and know how difficult and sometimes impossible it is to have clean water. I saw sickness in young and old due to dirty water.
